item.title: Destiny 2's Cheating Controversy Explained
item.description:
Destiny 2 is no stranger to cheating. Throughout its lifespan, countless players have been caught cheating in various aspects of the game, and especially in its more competitive scenes, like Crucible, Iron Banner, and Trials of Osiris. The use of aimbots, wallhacks, lag-switching, and net-limiting has long plagued the game's PvP activities, even after the implementation of BattlEye and its aim to put a full stop on cheating. Destiny 2 's PvP is far from the only arena affected by cheating, however, as even PvE cheating has slowly crept in over the years, with the most recent occurrence involving the game's latest raid.

One of the most coveted claims to fame in Destiny 2 is a day-one clear of a brand-new raid, but if players manage to conquer that raid within the first 48 hours of it being live, they're likely to feel just as accomplished. This is because new raids in Destiny 2 launch in Contest Mode for the first two days of their lifespan, which increases their difficulty across the board and thus makes completing them during that time period all the more sought after. Unfortunately, it seems the glory that awaits the players hoping to claim it tempted them a bit too much this time, as Destiny 2 's new Desert Perpetual raid saw an incredibly high illegitimate completion rate due to cheaters.

Destiny 2's Desert Perpetual Raid Was a Cheater’s Paradise

Community Investigators Have Uncovered Widespread Cheating Among Top Raid Clears

Within days of the new Desert Perpetual raid going live, players began combing through public raid data on RaidHub and other third-party sites because some things just weren't adding up almost immediately. The legitimate World First team, Team Nuts, took over 15 hours to beat the raid, all while livestreaming the entire process. However, not long after, dozens of other Desert Perpetual clears appeared on Raid Report that showed completion times as low as 20 minutes. Needless to say, such a massive gap between the lengthy clear time of the legitimate World First team and many others was off-putting, signaling that teams who were able to complete it in such a short amount of time were more than likely illegitimate, cheating clears.

Around 70% of Desert Perpetual raid clears were flagged as suspicious, which is unprecedented for a Destiny 2 raid.

Further investigation led to some not-so-surprising finds, with many of the teams that ranked in the top 100 clears of Contest Mode had players with extremely suspicious statistics. From incredibly fast clears and gear anomalies to kill count imbalances and low-history accounts, red flags were everywhere. Now, Destiny 2 's Contest Mode has never looked shakier in terms of competitive credibility, which couldn't have come at a worse time for the game as it struggles to maintain relevancy.

Destiny 2's Latest Contest Mode Raid Has Exposed a Massive Integrity Problem

It's one thing for PvP to see cheaters now and then, but an entirely different thing when cheating becomes such a widespread problem in Destiny 2 's core endgame content, which now includes the Desert Perpetual raid. Contest Mode raids are designed to reward the most prepared, coordinated, and dedicated teams, but when cheaters start flooding the leaderboards, everything Destiny 2 's endgame is built on begins to crack, revealing underlying issues and putting the game's foundational and structural integrity into question.

Now, Destiny 2 's Contest Mode has never looked shakier in terms of competitive credibility, which couldn't have come at a worse time for the game as it struggles to maintain relevancy.

Worse yet, it highlights how under-equipped Bungie may be to deal with large-scale PvE exploitation in real time. With layoffs in its Player Security division over the last couple of years and an aggressive cheat market, the Desert Perpetual raid controversy suggests that even Destiny 2 's most sacred traditions may no longer be safe without some serious changes to the game's framework and long-term viability as a live-service MMO in an increasingly critical climate.

item.title: Fallout: New Vegas Mod is a Game-Changer
item.description:
Iconic RPG Fallout: New Vegas is getting a dramatic visual overhaul on PC, with a fan-made project seeking to breathe new life into the game using cutting-edge visual techniques. The in-development mod aims to bring improved lighting, textures, material quality, and more to Fallout: New Vegas .

Released in 2010, Fallout: New Vegas is widely regarded among the best Fallout games ever made thanks to its deeply explorable world, exceptionally well-written plot lines, rich faction mechanics, and post-apocalyptic Western-inspired Mojave Desert setting. Despite its aging visuals and technical limitations, Fallout: New Vegas remains popular even a decade and a half after launch. While Obsidian and Bethesda remain tight-lipped on the prospect of a Fallout: New Vegas remaster or sequel, an active modding community on PC continues to support and expand the beloved RPG.

Modder and YouTuber skurtyyskirts has taken up the baton to rectify Fallout: New Vegas ' dated graphics with an ambitious Nvidia RTX Remix mod, which aims to heavily modernize the Mojave Wasteland visually. Built using the same toolkit behind Half-Life 2 RTX, this in-progress mod introduces fully path-traced lighting, realistic PBR (Physically Based Rendering) materials, and nearly complete texture overhauls for Fallout: New Vegas . Interior shots, like those of the Goodsprings saloon, already show noticeable visual upgrades, with neon lights casting dynamic glows and surfaces reflecting with newfound depth.

Everything the Fallout: New Vegas RTX Mod Adds to The Game

  • Fully path-traced visuals, including physically accurate shadows, reflections, and global illumination.
  • Full PBR (Physically-Based Rendering) material overhaul for nearly every in-game asset.
  • "Iconic" weapons, armor, and terminals have been completely remastered by hand in Substance Painter.
  • Dynamic "sun-shafts" through broken rooftops and per-light volumetrics to make interiors feel appropriately dusty and atmospheric.
  • High-fidelity details, like irradiated water puddles that realistically reflect the broken world and cracked asphalt roads with full height-map details.
  • Pip-Boy and certain active computer terminals feature subtle Nvidia green accents and glows as a nod to the underlying tech of the mod.

According to skurtyyskirts, the Fallout: New Vegas RTX mod is now in full production following strong community support, and there are no plans to use AI-generated textures; each asset will be handcrafted for quality and authenticity. However, not everything translates seamlessly. Some have lamented the absence of Fallout: New Vegas ' hallmark orange-brown color palette - a product of its pre-baked lighting and post-apocalyptic art direction. While this does enhance realism, the cleaner and more photorealistic aesthetic can compromise some of the original game's intended atmosphere, especially in outdoor scenes.

Fallout: New Vegas RTX is also part of ModDB's RTX Remix contest, which features a $50,000 prize pool and has given rise to similar visual overhaul projects for iconic PC games like Quake , Manhunt , and Max Payne . With no official remaster or sequel to Fallout: New Vegas in sight, skurtyyskirts' RTX mod might well be the closest fans get to a modern version of Obsidian's classic RPG, but only on PC.

item.title: August 7 is Going to Be a Big Day for Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 Fans
item.description:
Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 's fifth season will arrive on August 7, 2025. While Black Ops 7 has taken much of the spotlight lately, support for the current Call of Duty generation is still ongoing, and fans still have more to look forward to in the game. In a little over a week, the somewhat controversial Season 4 will come to an end, and Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 Season 5 will begin.

The past season has not been a huge success for Activision. While Season 3 was met with praise and excitement, Black Ops and Warzone fans called Season 4 a dumpster fire, citing a slew of bugs, crashes, in-game ads, and unpopular gameplay changes. Whether the upcoming season will live up to the game's previous standard is unclear, but at least players won't have to wait long to find out.

The official Call of Duty Twitter account posted on July 28 to confirm that Season 5 would come to Black Ops 6 and Warzone on August 7. The brief but informative update also confirmed that Sims would be returning as an operator, and the accompanying image shows Sims carrying the M249 SAW. Activision had teased the M249 in a Black Ops 6 Season 5 trailer, but now that it graces the key art for the season's official announcement, any uncertainty about the LMG's return to the series is all but dispelled.

Season 5 of Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 and Warzone Begins August 7

A nine-second teaser from Treyarch on July 23 also hinted at a new map for Black Ops 6 's Zombies mode, which is a welcome addition considering Season 4 did not introduce another Zombies map. It will likely also be the last such addition to the game, given both Treyarch's wording and the approaching release of Black Ops 7 later this year. The official Season 5 announcement on Twitter didn't mention any specifics about Zombies or other updates, but fans can learn more firsthand before long.

Looking beyond Black Ops 6 , the next installment in the Call of Duty franchise still lacks a release date, but an August 17 deep dive should clarify things. It's rumored that Black Ops 7 may release on November 14, which would give players plenty of time to enjoy Season 5 of the current generation before moving on to the next. In any case, new Call of Duty content is arriving shortly in one form or another, and many are excited to see if the new content will be able to improve the game's current image.

item.title: Pokemon Shadow Drops New App
item.description:
Pokemon surprised fans by dropping a new app called Play Pokemon Access. Given the high level of activity in the Pokemon competitive scene and events in general, this app will be very helpful.

Pokemon has long had a competitive side to it, ever since 1997 during the Nintendo Cup, where players of Pokemon Red and Blue battled. This would eventually move on to the card game as well, with the first Pokemon Trading Card Game World Championship being held in 2004. There is still a strong number of players to this day playing Pokemon competitively, both in video game and card game form, with the Pokemon North America International Championships happening in June 2025.

As reported by Pocket Tactics, Pokemon made a surprise shadow drop of a new app called Play Pokemon Access. This allows players interested in playing competitively to find tournaments and events that are being held in their area. This includes events for the video games, the Pokemon Trading Card Game , and Pokemon GO . This means that, for example, fans can use the new app to keep track of where to go for the new Pokemon GO event that was recently announced.

Play Pokemon Access Helps Players Learn How to Play Competitively

The Play Pokemon Access app can be great with players familiar with playing competitive Pokemon , as well as new fans who want to get into the scene. For newer competitors, they will be able to read about all the rules, all the banned Pokemon, and a full database of the Pokemon Trading Card Game , allowing them to start as prepared as possible. Veterans will appreciate being able to view their championship points and look at team sheets, as well as all of the other features, if they need a refresher. Additionally, players will be able to collect badges within the app by taking part in sanctioned events. This is coming out at a perfect time, as the Pokemon Trading Card Game is preparing for its new set.

Pokemon fans have a lot to look forward to. Between the new card set coming soon and changing the game, and the Pokemon Presents earlier in July giving many new reveals, fans will have many new and updated ways to enjoy the franchise. Play Pokemon Access will help fans keep track of many of these aspects and play them competitively. However, they will still need to register for these events either in person or through a third-party app. Hopefully, these features will be integrated into the app in the future, making it even more convenient for competitors.

item.title: Magic: The Gathering is Casting a 2-Mana Black Instant From 2002 on The Entire Fanbase
item.description:
One could argue that 2025 has been one of the busiest years for Wizards of the Coast and Magic: The Gathering , and regardless of whether they are new fans or longtime players, there is quite some truth to this. November 2024 saw the release of the Foundations set, which is supposed to stay in Magic: The Gathering 's Standard format for at least 5 years, but the plan is semi-perpetuity. 2025 saw the release of four sets so far, counting the Innistrad Remastered products in January, and there are still three to go. This may be ascribed to MTG 's Universes Beyond sets taking much more space on the schedule, but it's not just that.

It doesn't really matter what the sets being released are, as the problem is the way the schedule has been set up in terms of all the various releases, their information cycles and spoiler seasons, and how all this is affecting the game and its fans. In a way, Wizards of the Coast is casting Magic: The Gathering 's Smother on the community, not necessarily for its effect, but for what it stands for - asphyxiation. There's a certain fatigue one can experience when keeping up with every set release, and with the way the hobby is built, there is very little wiggle room about who should care about it and who shouldn't.

Smother is a 2-CMC (1 generic, 1 Black) Black instant from the 2002 Onslaught set, and it destroys a creature with CMC 3 or less.

Magic: The Gathering's Release Schedule and Information Cycle is a Double-Edged Sword

Currently, Magic: The Gathering 's Edge of Eternities set is in its pre-release phase, fully launching on August 1, and WotC has already revealed around 100 cards from the September Spider-Man set, while also sporadically revealing cards for the November Avatar: The Last Airbender set. The same happened with Aetherdrift, Tarkir: Dragonstorm, and Final Fantasy . Some release dates are clustered together, and while that may be for marketing reasons or simply because that's what happens with six or seven sets in a year, it can be a bit too much.

MTG 's Avatar Aang card was revealed in June, five months before its respective set would be released, and now the recent conference in San Diego revealed the full extent of what to expect from the Spider-Man set, including a plethora of new cards for the main set and even some from the Eternal side. All this is not easy to keep up with when most formats in the game will use these new cards, with Standard being bombarded with new sets and constantly changing its meta.

MTG's Release Schedule and News Fatigue May Persist Through 2026

It seems very likely that Magic: The Gathering 's 2026 release schedule will be almost identical to that of 2025, maybe without the typical Remastered set or extra release, as WotC's own Mark Rosewater confirmed that the plan for the near future is to have a 50/50 split for in-multiverse and Universes Beyond sets. Considering that 2026 will mark the release of Lorwyn Eclisped, Secrets of Strixhaven, and the codename Ziplining set, it's fair to assume that there will be three UB sets in the mix.

It could be argued that the only format that is mostly immune to all the news cycles, hype cycles, spoiler seasons, and constant releases is Magic: The Gathering 's Commander, as players will most likely only ever need a few cards from each release, if any at all, to add to their decks. As such, it's a tall task for the average player to keep track of all the news, spoilers, release dates, prerelease dates, products being sold, MTG Arena bundles, format changes, and everything in between, while also having the time to actually play the game.

For example, Edge of Eternities' Tannuk, Steadfast Second, is being talked about for all the combos it enables, including a powerful synergy with Portal to Phyrexia. However, with everything going on, one might not realize that this combo won't be available in Standard, as Edge of Eternities marks when the next rotation happens, and Portal to Phyrexia will rotate out of the format.

Magic: The Gathering's Constant Releases May Backfire After Final Fantasy's Success

What follows is that, while many players are and may be hyped by all the new releases in 2025, the constant updates may end up taking a toll on the community sooner rather than later. Magic: The Gathering 's Final Fantasy set earned $200 million in a single day, and a lot of new players or collectors inevitably got into the game thanks to this specific release, but it remains to be seen whether they are willing to keep up with everything once the new fad is over.

Considering all the gameplay intricacies and the many rules and rule-bending cards in Magic: The Gathering , this game is often more than just a hobby for those who partake in it actively. As such, a slew of announcements, updates, changes, and new releases can be perceived as a "second job," making the TCG less of a hobby and more akin to live-service video games.

This is not necessarily a bad thing for those who enjoy this aspect, but the whole package can feel like too much to handle for a layperson or casual fan, and it could counteract the introductory aspect of Universes Beyond sets in MTG in the long run. Still, there are many cool cards coming out this year after Edge of Eternities, regardless of where one stands about the UB sets flowing through Standard, and with enough time and patience, the new release schedule can also be a blessing in disguise.
